biogHists.text:
Cornell University Class of 1927, Ph.D. 1933; professor of speech.

From the description of Karl Richards Wallace papers, [ca. 1925-1967]. (Cornell University Library). WorldCat record id: 64073262

relations.content: Cornell University. Dept. of Speech and Drama.

resource.source:
Karl R. Wallace Papers 1940-74 15/23/22 Wallace, Karl Richards, 1905-1973 1.30 English University of Illinois Archives
19 Library 1408 W. Gregory Dr. Urbana, IL, URL: http://archives.library.illinois.edu Email: illiarch@illinois.edu Phone: (217) 333-0798 Fax: (217) 333-2868

Other Information:

2 Pages

Additional information may be found at http://archives.library.illinois.edu/uasfa/1523022.pdf

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:648006513</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-VA064</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Lewis, Ivey Foreman, 1882-1964,</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>University of Virginia announcements and circular letters [manuscript], 1939-1945.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection contains an announcement for a discussion by Karl R. Wallace of speech instruction in public schools, 1939; a fund raising letter from the University Field Club, 1939; form letter used for College of Arts and Sciences catalog request, 1939; circular from Dean George O. Ferguson concerning absences; notes to advisers by [I. F.?] Lewis on the installation of an advisory system which would aid failing students with handwritten comment "infantile"; a list of administrative committees of the faculty, 1942-43 and their members; circular letter from Dean Lewis to students regarding penalties for bringing women into their rooms, 1943; </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>University of Virginia</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: University of Virginia announcements and circular letters [manuscript], 1939-1945.
resource.abstract: The collection contains an announcement for a discussion by Karl R. Wallace of speech instruction in public schools, 1939; a fund raising letter from the University Field Club, 1939; form letter used for College of Arts and Sciences catalog request, 1939; circular from Dean George O. Ferguson concerning absences; notes to advisers by [I. F.?] Lewis on the installation of an advisory system which would aid failing students with handwritten comment "infantile"; a list of administrative committees of the faculty, 1942-43 and their members; circular letter from Dean Lewis to students regarding penalties for bringing women into their rooms, 1943;

                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Speeches delivered at the University of Virginia [manuscript] 1904-1947 (bulk 1938-1940).</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection contains lectures in a theology series, 1936 -1940, by Mortimer Adler, Norman P. Cohen, James M. Egan, O.P., Frank A. Geldard, Lewis M. Hammond, D. Clark Hyde, L. F. Kinney, William H. Laird, S. Vernon McCasland, Marcus B. Mallett, A. T. Mollegen, Howard Newman (notes only), J. Winfree Smith, William Kyle Smith, Carroll Mason Sparrow, Joseph Strause (notes only), and William S. Weedon. Sparrow's essay on "The measure of measurement" was later published in "Voyages and Cargoes." The collection also contains lectures in a great authors series by A.D. Fraser, W.A. Montgomery and Frederic T. Wood. Speeches on University of Virginia topics incude the honor system by Virginius Dabney; Paul B. Barringer by Roy Flanangan; a debate before the Jefferson Society by Robert W. Hoel; the 8th evac by H.E. Jordan; a comparison of the University in 1896 and 1924 by James M. Page; the "gay nineties" at Virginia by Lewis C. Williams; Other speakers include Sir Harold Bellman, A. D. Fraser, Garrard Glenn, James Hart, W. Edwin Hemphill, A. A. Hill, C[linton?] N[ewton?] Howard, William H. Laird, Ivey F. Lewis, John C. Metcalf, Julius M. Parmlee, Charles Pergler, Homer Richey, Joseph K. Roberts,Karl R. Wallace, Sumner Welles, Jennings C. Wise, Frederick T. Wood, David M. Wright. Miscellaneous ittems include a catalog of prints by Oscar Gieberich on exhibit 1939. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>University of Virginia</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Speeches delivered at the University of Virginia [manuscript] 1904-1947 (bulk 1938-1940).
resource.abstract: The collection contains lectures in a theology series, 1936 -1940, by Mortimer Adler, Norman P. Cohen, James M. Egan, O.P., Frank A. Geldard, Lewis M. Hammond, D. Clark Hyde, L. F. Kinney, William H. Laird, S. Vernon McCasland, Marcus B. Mallett, A. T. Mollegen, Howard Newman (notes only), J. Winfree Smith, William Kyle Smith, Carroll Mason Sparrow, Joseph Strause (notes only), and William S. Weedon. Sparrow's essay on "The measure of measurement" was later published in "Voyages and Cargoes." The collection also contains lectures in a great authors series by A.D. Fraser, W.A. Montgomery and Frederic T. Wood. Speeches on University of Virginia topics incude the honor system by Virginius Dabney; Paul B. Barringer by Roy Flanangan; a debate before the Jefferson Society by Robert W. Hoel; the 8th evac by H.E. Jordan; a comparison of the University in 1896 and 1924 by James M. Page; the "gay nineties" at Virginia by Lewis C. Williams; Other speakers include Sir Harold Bellman, A. D. Fraser, Garrard Glenn, James Hart, W. Edwin Hemphill, A. A. Hill, C[linton?] N[ewton?] Howard, William H. Laird, Ivey F. Lewis, John C. Metcalf, Julius M. Parmlee, Charles Pergler, Homer Richey, Joseph K. Roberts,Karl R. Wallace, Sumner Welles, Jennings C. Wise, Frederick T. Wood, David M. Wright. Miscellaneous ittems include a catalog of prints by Oscar Gieberich on exhibit 1939.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <unittitle>Francis Bacon Library
				Archive</unittitle>
                  <unitdate>1846-1996</unitdate>
                  <unitdate>1920-1990</unitdate>
                  <unitid>602120</unitid>
                  <origination>
                     <corpname>Francis Bacon Foundation</corpname>
                  </origination>
                  <physdesc>
                     <extent>151 boxes/83.3 linear feet</extent>
                  </physdesc>
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>The Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens,
						<subarea>Rare Books Department</subarea>
                     </corpname>
                     <address>
                        <addressline>1151 Oxford Road</addressline>
                        <addressline>San Marino, California 91108</addressline>
                        <addressline>Phone: (626) 405-2181</addressline>
                        <addressline>Fax: (626) 449-5720</addressline>
                        <addressline>Email: soatey@huntington.org
</addressline>
                        <addressline>URL: http://www.huntington.org</addressline>
                     </address>
                  </repository>
                  <abstract>The Francis Bacon Library was a
				private rare book research library on the campus of the Claremont Colleges in
				Claremont, California. It was founded by Walter Conrad Arensberg and his wife,
				Louise Stevens Arensberg. In 1938, they established The Francis Bacon Foundation to
				promote study of the life and works of statesman Sir Francis Bacon (1561-1626). The
				Foundation administered the Francis Bacon Library, which included a comprehensive
				collection on the Shakespeare authorship controversy, a subject of great personal
				interest to Walter Arensberg, who believed that Bacon was the true author of
				Shakespeare's plays. This archive contains the records of the Library, which closed
				in 1995, including papers and correspondence of scholars interested in Bacon and the
				authorship question. It also contains the personal and family papers of the
				Arensbergs, and Walter Arensberg’s cryptographic files and research on the
				authorship controversy. </abstract>
                  <langmaterial>The records are in <language>English</language>. </langmaterial>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Francis Bacon LibraryArchive 1846-1996 1920-1990
resource.abstract: The Francis Bacon Library was aprivate rare book research library on the campus of the Claremont Colleges inClaremont, California. It was founded by Walter Conrad Arensberg and his wife,Louise Stevens Arensberg. In 1938, they established The Francis Bacon Foundation topromote study of the life and works of statesman Sir Francis Bacon (1561-1626). TheFoundation administered the Francis Bacon Library, which included a comprehensivecollection on the Shakespeare authorship controversy, a subject of great personalinterest to Walter Arensberg, who believed that Bacon was the true author ofShakespeare's plays. This archive contains the records of the Library, which closedin 1995, including papers and correspondence of scholars interested in Bacon and theauthorship question. It also contains the personal and family papers of theArensbergs, and Walter Arensberg’s cryptographic files and research on theauthorship controversy.
